Chapter 9  
Independence  
The concept of independence is the ï¬rst important notion of probability theory that  
is not a simple adaptation of similar notions in measure theory. If it is easier to  
have an intuitive understanding of what the independence of two events or of two  
random variables means, the most fundamental concept is the independence of two  
(or several) Ïƒ-ï¬elds.  
A key result relates the independence of two random variables to the fact that  
the law of the pair made of these two variables is equal to the product measure  
of the individual laws. Together with the Fubini theorem, this leads to useful  
reformulations of the notion of independence. We establish the famous Borel-  
Cantelli lemma, and as an application we derive surprising properties of the dyadic  
expansion of a real number chosen at random. We use Lebesgue measure and this  
dyadic expansion to give an elementary construction of sequences of independent  
(real) random variables, which sufï¬ces for our needs in the following chapters. We  
pay special attention to sums of independent and identically distributed random  
variables. In particular we give a ï¬rst version of the law of large numbers, which  
provides a link between our axiomatic presentation of probability theory and the  
â€œhistoricalâ€ approach, where the probability of an event is the asymptotic frequency  
of occurence of this event when the random experiment is repeated a large number of  
times. The last section, which may be omitted at ï¬rst reading, is a brief presentation  
of the Poisson process, which illustrates many of the notions introduced in this  
chapter.

9.1 Independent Events  
Throughout this chapter, we consider a probability space (Î©, A, P). If A, B âˆˆ A  
are two events, we say that A and B are independent if  
P(A âˆ© B) = P(A)P(B).  
If P(B) > 0, we can interpret this deï¬nition by saying that the conditional  
probability  
P(A âˆ© B)  
P(A | B) (d=ef)  
P(B)  
is equal to P(A): knowing that B holds gives no information on whether A holds or  
not (and the roles of A and B can be interchanged).  
Examples  
2
(i) Throwing two dice : Î© = {1, 2, . . . , 6} , P({Ï‰}) = 1/36 for every Ï‰ âˆˆ Î©. The  
events A = {6} Ã— {1, 2, . . . , 6} (6 at the ï¬rst trial) and B = {1, 2, . . . , 6} Ã— {6}  
(6 at the second trial) are independent. In fact the probability measure P has  
been constructed so that any event concerning the ï¬rst trial is independent of  
any event concerning the second trial.  
(ii) Throwing one die : Î© = {1, 2, . . . , 6}, P({Ï‰}) = 1/6 for every Ï‰ âˆˆ Î©. The  
events A = {1, 2} and B = {1, 3, 5} are independent.  
Deï¬nition 9.1 We say that n events A1, . . . , An are independent if, for every  
nonempty subset {j1, . . . , jp} of {1, . . . , n}, we have  
P(Aj âˆ© Aj âˆ© . . . âˆ© Aj ) = P(Aj ) P(Aj ) . . . P(Aj ).

9.2 Independence for Ïƒ-Fields and Random Variables  
We say that B is a sub-Ïƒ-ï¬eld of A if B is a Ïƒ-ï¬eld and B âŠ‚ A. Roughly speaking,  
a sub-Ïƒ-ï¬eld B corresponds to some partial information in the probability space,  
namely the information given by knowing which events in B have occurred (for  
instance, if B = Ïƒ(X) where X is a random variable, the corresponding information  
is just the value of X). This suggests that the most general notion of independence  
is that of independent sub-Ïƒ-ï¬elds: informally, two sub-Ïƒ-ï¬elds B and Bê¢ƒ will  
be independent if knowing which events of B have occurred does not give any  
information on the occurrence of events of Bê¢ƒ, and conversely. We make this more  
precise in the following deï¬nition.  
Deï¬nition 9.3 Let B1, . . . , Bn be n sub-Ïƒ-ï¬elds of A. We say that B1, . . . , Bn are  
independent if, for every A1 âˆˆ B1, A2 âˆˆ B2, . . . , An âˆˆ Bn,  
P(A1 âˆ© A2 âˆ© . . . âˆ© An) = P(A1) P(A2) . . . P(An).

Independence  
Let X1, . . . , Xn be n random variables taking values in (E1, E1), . . . , (En, En)  
respectively. We say that the random variables X1, . . . , Xn are independent if the  
Ïƒ-ï¬elds Ïƒ(X1), . . . , Ïƒ(Xn) are independent. This is equivalent to saying that the  
property  
P({X1 âˆˆ F1} âˆ© . . . âˆ© {Xn âˆˆ Fn}) = P(X1 âˆˆ F1) . . . P(Xn âˆˆ Fn)  
(9.1)  
holds for every F1 âˆˆ E1, . . . , Fn âˆˆ En.  
The fact that (9.1) is equivalent to the independence of Ïƒ(X1), . . . , Ïƒ(Xn) is  
clear since Ïƒ(Xj ) = {Xjâˆ’1(F) : F âˆˆ Ej }, for every j âˆˆ {1, . . . , p}, as we saw in  
Section 8.1.7. Informally, the random variables X1, . . . , Xn are independent if the  
knowledge of a subset of these variables does not give information on the remaining  
ones.  
It will also be useful to consider the independence of several (ï¬nite or inï¬nite)  
collections of random variables, which is deï¬ned in the obvious manner. For  
instance, two collections (Xi)iâˆˆI and (Yj )jâˆˆJ of random variables are independent  
if the Ïƒ-ï¬elds Ïƒ((Xi)iâˆˆI ) and Ïƒ((Yj )jâˆˆJ ) are independent. Note that this is stronger  
than just saying that Xi and Yj are independent for every i âˆˆ I and j âˆˆ J.  
Remarks  
(i) If B1, . . . , Bn are n independent sub-Ïƒ-ï¬elds of A, and if, for every i âˆˆ  
{1, . . . , n}, Xi is a Bi-measurable random variable, then X1, . . . , Xn are  
independent (this is obvious since saying that Xi is Bi-measurable is equivalent  
to Ïƒ(Xi) âŠ‚ Bi).  
(ii) The n events A1, . . . , An are independent if and only if the Ïƒ-ï¬elds  
Ïƒ(A1), . . . , Ïƒ(An) are independent (Proposition 9.2).

Theorem 9.4 also shows how to construct (ï¬nitely many) independent random

Let us turn to the relation between independence and covariance.  
Corollary 9.5 If X1, X2 are two independent real random variables in L2, then  
cov(X1, X2) = 0.  
This follows from the preceding remarks since cov(X1, X2) = E[X1X2] âˆ’  
E[X1]E[X2].  
The converse to the corollary is false. The property cov(X1, X2) = 0 is much  
weaker than the independence of X1 and X2. To give a simple example, let X1 be  
a real random variable having a symmetric density p(x) = p(âˆ’x) and such that  
ê¢„
x2p(x)dx < âˆž (so that X1 âˆˆ L2). Let Y be another random variable, with  
values in {âˆ’1, 1}, such that P(Y = 1) = P(Y = âˆ’1) = 12, and assume that Y is  
independent of X1. Then, setting X2 = ÎµX1, we easily get  
cov(X1, X2) = E[X1X2] = E[Y(X1)2] = E[Y]E[(X1)2] = 0,  
but X1 and X2 are not independent. Indeed, if X1 and X2 were independent, |X1|  
would be independent of |X2| = |X1|, and it is easy to see that a real random  
variable cannot be independent of itself unless it is constant a.s.

9.4 Construction of Independent Sequences  
Many of the developments that follow are devoted to the study of sequences of  
independent and identically distributed random variables. An obvious question is the  
existence of such sequences on an appropriate probability space. The natural way

Proposition 9.4, when we explained how to construct ï¬nitely many independent

some measure-theoretic difï¬culties, we present here a more elementary approach,

book (even for the construction of Brownian motion in Chapter 14).

Since a countable union of sets of zero probability has probability zero, we conclude  
that the following holds: for every Ï‰ âˆˆ [0, 1), except on a set of Lebesgue measure  
0, the property (9.4) holds simultaneously for every p â‰¥ 1 and every choice of  
i1, . . . , ip âˆˆ {0, 1}.  
In other words, for almost every real Ï‰ âˆˆ [0, 1), the asymptotic frequency of  
occurence of any ï¬nite block of 0 and 1 in the dyadic expansion of Ï‰ exists and is  
equal to 2âˆ’p, where p is the length of the block. Note that it is not easy to exhibit  
just one real Ï‰ âˆˆ [0, 1) for which the latter property holds. In fact the fastest way to  
prove that such reals do exist is certainly the probabilistic argument we have given.  
This is typical of applications of probability theory to existence problems: to get the  
existence of an object having certain properties, one shows that an object chosen  
at random (according to an appropriate probability distribution) will almost surely  
satisfy the desired properties.

9.7 The Poisson Process  
In this section, we introduce and study the Poisson process, which is one of the most  
important random processes in probability theory (together with Brownian motion,  
which will be studied in Chapter 14). The study of the Poisson process will illustrate  
many of the preceding results about independence.

The Poisson process is very often used in applied probability models, for instance  
in queueing theory, where Nt represents the number of customers arriving at a  
server before time t. The fact that the exponential distribution is chosen to model  
the period between two successive arrivals of customers is related to the property  
of lack of memory of this distribution (see Section 8.1.5). Roughly speaking, this  
property says that, for any given time t â‰¥ 0, the time between t and the next  
arrival of a customer has always the same distribution independently of what has  
happened before time t (we will formulate this in more precise mathematical terms  
in Theorem 9.21 below).
